titleInfo.title: Photograph of Annie Sybil Thomas Jarrett, 1910s

location.physicalLocation: Special Collections Division of the Nashville Public Library, 615 Church Street, Nashville, Tennessee, 37219

mods.abstract: Black and white studio photograph of Annie Sybil Thomas Jarrett, likely taken in Paris, Tennessee. She is wearing a dark colored blouse with a jeweled pin and dark necklace and earrings. The back of the portrait includes family information including that Jarrett is descended from Annie Combs, an enslaved woman. Annie Sybil Thomas Jarrett (1881-1975) was a teacher and lifelong member of the Republican Party. She was born near Saulsbury, Tennessee. She is the daughter of Harriet and John Thomas Sr. She attended Clay Street School in Memphis, Tennessee, which later became the site of Booker T. Washington High School. She graduated with a degree in education from Lane College. She advocated in her community and schools for the teaching of African American history. According to family tradition, she urged family members to vote Republican to honor Abraham Lincoln and the Emancipation Proclamation.

titleInfo.title: Generations - African American Women's Early Activism in Tennessee
